document.docAuthor: Rodrigues, Everton Nei Lopes & Brescovit, Antonio Domingos
document.docTitle: Asemostera dianae Rodrigues & Brescovit, 2012, new species
document.masterDocTitle: Linyphiid spiders of Peru: description of a new species, complementary descriptions and new distribution records (Araneae: Linyphiidae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Linyphiid spiders of Peru: description of a new species, complementary descriptions and new distribution records (Araneae: Linyphiidae)

subSubSection.paragraph:
Types .
Holotype male from Peru , Madre de Dios, Zona Reservada Pakitza (bosque), 356 m a.s.l. (above sea level),
04.III. 1991
, D. Silva col., deposited in MUSM ENT 0 0 503897 . Paratype female, same data as the holotype , deposited in MUSM ENT 0 0 508000 . Paratypes , four males and seven females, same data as the holotype , deposited in MUSM ENT 0 0 508001 . Paratypes , male and female from Peru , Cuzco, Acjanaco–Tres Cruces,
13 .III. 1991
, D. Silva col., deposited in IBSP 162933 .

Etymology. The specific name honors the arachnologist Diana Silva, collector of the type specimens series and curator of the arachnological collection of Museo de Historia Natural da Universidad Nacional Mayor de San Marcos, Lima, Peru .

Diagnosis. The male of
Asemostera dianae
new species
resembles that of
A. enkidu
Miller, 2007
(
Miller, 2007 : 173 , figs. 124 H, 127 E, F, I
) by the less developed radix (
Fig. 2
), but differs by the following: shorter retrolateral tibial apophysis (
Fig. 1
), less developed paracymbium, embolic membrane developed and enlarged ( Figs. 1, 2 ), tegulum with duct sinuous and not forming a loop (
Fig. 1
), and embolus longer than
A. enkidu
(
Fig 2
). The female of
Asemostera dianae
new species
is closest to that of
A. pallida (
Millidge, 1991
)
(see
Miller, 2007
: 173 , figs. 124 I, 128 G, O, P) based on the presence of short copulatory ducts, fertilization ducts oriented mesally from posterior part of spermathecae, and epigynum with ventral plate scape, but differs by the less developed ventral plate scape, which does not surpass the posterior margin of epigynum (
Fig. 6
), and more closely adjacent copulatory ducts (
Fig. 7
).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 1–7.
Asemostera dianae
new species
: (1, 2) Male palp: (1) ectal, (2) mesal, (3) tibia, dorsal. (4) Male carapace, ventral. (5) Female palpi. (6, 7) Epigynum: (6) ventral, (7) dorsal, cleared. (ARP: anterior radical process; CG: retrobasal cymbial groove; DP: dorsal plate; E: embolus; EM: embolic membrane; FD: fertilization duct; PTA: prolateral tibial apophysis; R: radix; RTA: retrolateral tibial apophysis; S: spermathecae; Sc: scape; SPT: suprategulum; ST: subtegulum; T: tegulum; VP: ventral plate). Scale lines: 0.25 mm.

subSubSection.paragraph: Variation. Males (n= 5 ): total length 2.1–2.31 ; carapace length 1.02–1.11 . Females (n= 5 ): total length 1.91–2.33 ; carapace length 0.81–0.88 . The color pattern is quite variable from dark-brown to brown in carapace and abdomen dark-grey to grey in both sexes.

Material examined. PERU . Cuzco : Acjanaco–Tres Cruces,
13 .III. 1991
, D. Silva col., 1 Ƥ ( MUSM ENT 0503954);
6 .III. 1991
, D. Silva col., 23, 2Ƥ ( MUSM ENT 00503974); Madre de Dios : Zona Reservada Pakitza (bosque), D. Silva col., 356m , 07.VII.1991 , 43 ( MUSM ENT 00503909); 02.VII.1991 , 23 ( MUSM ENT 00503965); 03.VII.1991 , 13 ( MUSM ENT 00503966); 04.VII.1991 , 13, 3 Ƥ ( MUSM ENT 00503967); 13 ( MUSM ENT 00503973).
Distribution. Peru (Cuzco and Madre de Dios).
